title: argyllshire advertiser leader column june 18 2021 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 3 3 3 2 3 2 3 2 3 2
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Surely the council must accept its plans # even as outline proposals # for school clusters should be reconsidered.Teachers are largely opposed, unions are against it, parent councils are certainly in opposition. And the way it has been conducted gives the impression of it being a #done deal# rather than a genuine consultation.It has been badly handled # a boorach. But, fair or not, perhaps the threat of candidates losing votes in May over their stance on the issue might focus political minds in Kilmory.Millions have left Ukraine with almost nothing, leaving loved ones behind and seeking refuge.We hear of a number of Mid Argyll folk ready to accept Ukrainian families into their homes and properties.And the efforts of volunteers to arrange much-needed supplies from the people of Argyll, led by Amanda in Lochgilphead, is tremendous.We see people organising packs for Ukrainian children, MacLeods offering work, accommodation and dignity to people in desperate need, Kilmory shinty club donating the proceeds of their lottery, Lochgilphead golfers donating generously#the list goes on.Well done to all # but help will be needed for a long time to come.

title: news from the districts june 18 2021 2 2 2 2 2 4 4 2 2 3
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.CCTV is coming to two hotspots for gatherings of young people in Helensburgh, police have confirmed after tobacco and alcohol were confiscated from youths.The equipment is due to be installed in Hermitage Park and Churchill Square.In a report to Argyll and Bute Council’s Helensburgh and Lomond area committee, Police Inspector Alan Heron also said that the new speed camera which has recently been installed in Cardross should be operational by the end of April # and more could be coming in the future.Inspector Heron said: #Youth disorder and general anti-social behaviour has not been a major issue for us over the winter months but that is what we would generally expect.#Such issues are generally seasonal and we would expect to see a rise in youth disorder as we enter the spring with improved weather and lighter nights.#There were a few nights in February when youths were congregating in Hermitage Park. We ran a local action plan to deal with this, resulting in a number of youths being taken home, tobacco and alcohol being confiscated and fixed penalty notices being issued.#In the coming months new CCTV systems are due to be installed in both Hermitage Park and Churchill Square which should act as a deterrent in these two sometimes problematic locations.#Road crime and road safety continues to be the focus of a large part of our operational activity. This is no surprise given the roads network in the Helensburgh and Lomond area.#The first and only fixed site speed camera in Argyll and West Dunbartonshire Division has recently been installed on the A in the centre of Cardross.#The camera should become operational by the end of April  following a period of testing. The main aim of this speed camera is to positively influence driver behaviour and improve road safety.#Depending on its effectiveness we will hopefully see more being rolled out where in Argyll in the future.#Inspector Heron added: #Our main focus at the moment is planning for the start of the tourist season over the Easter holidays and beyond as we go into the summer months.#The influx of tourists to Loch Lomondside and the surrounding areas places a strain on local infrastructure and our policing demands also increase correspondingly.#We are working with our partners in Argyll and Bute Council and the Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park Authority to have plans and contingencies in place to deal with the anticipated demands.#Under the well-known Cowal Open Studios banner, there will be two new opportunities this Easter for visitors to explore the Cowal peninsula and see artists at work.As well as the traditional Cowal Open Studios weekend in September, look out for Cowal Art at Easter, to be held over the weekend of April -, when each studio will be open between am and pm.Keep an eye on the cowalopenstudios website for more details.The ladies of Lochgilphead SWI were earlier this month treated to a fascinating talk and show of the most amazing quilts by Chrystine Livingston.She talked of how her journey into quilting started and quickly developed. This led to signing up and for a City and Guilds course.Chrystine is a member of the Turning Point Art Textiles group which regularly exhibits in galleries across Scotland and beyond.Members were fascinated with the detail in her work which was evident when viewed up close.Lochgilphead SWI offered grateful thanks to Chrystine for giving members a very enjoyable evening.A big Easter event is planned in Furnace.Following the success of last year#s Furnace Easter Eggstravaganza, Sunday April  has been set for this year#s event.Organised by community organisation Furnace Community SCIO along with David and Cindy of Furnace Village Stores, the day promises a raffle described as #giant# and plenty more fun besides.If anyone can spare a gt for the raffle, they are welcome to leave it in the shop or speak to a member of the SCIO.Put the date in your diary#Hundreds of pounds have been raised so far after dookers took a dip at Ganavan near  Oban for Argyll and Bute Women#s Aid.Swimmers from Loch Awe, Kilchrennan, Benderloch, Oban, Seil, Luing and Crinan braved grey skies on Saturday March  to take the International Women#s Day charity plunge together.Money raised will help Argyll and Bute Women’s Aid  provide information and support to women, as well as children and young people living with domestic abuse in the area.Earlier this week, the event’s Justgiving appeal stood around the £ mark.Visit www.justgiving fundraising obaniwdyou would like to donate.

title: positive talks on the rest with new minister
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowA group pressing for urgency at the Rest and be Thankful has wasted no time since a recent meeting with a UK government minister # as its members last week held #positive# talks with Scottish Government Transport Minister Jenny Gilruth.Despite transport policy being reserved to Holyrood, the business-led Rest and be Thankful Campaign met Scotland Office minister Iain Stewart on March  to press for help in speeding up the construction of a replacement for the A past the landslide-hit Rest and be Thankful.Campaigners argue that the approach being taken by Transport Scotland is too slow # scheduled to take up to  years # and hidebound in processes which could and should be undertaken with much more urgency.At the Inveraray gathering Mr Stewart, while giving no guarantees, agreed to look at options around funding to aid the early stage design process, while civil servants pursue other potential UK funding sources.Mr Stewart, though, can only influence the process so much.The real authority lies with the Scottish Government, so on March  representatives of the campaign group # Argyll Estates factor Hugh Nicol and NFU Scotland regional chair Duncan Macalister of Glenbarr Farm # met new Transport Minister Jenny Gilruth to discuss the matter.Mr Nicol said: #Jenny kindly met the group at the Rest and be Thankful within weeks of her appointment, something we have not seen from [former ministers] Michael Matheson or Graeme Dey.#This was a very positive meeting she was keen to engage with us and question why we can#t make a decision on the solution for the RABT now.##It was good to see Jenny has local roots,# said Mr Macalister. #Her family comes from Lochgilphead and Inveraray area, which showed in her appreciation of the importance of the transport links from Argyll to the rest of Scotland.#We were encouraged by her positive response to our call for action, and look forward to seeing fresh thinking and progress to a solution soon.#Rest and be Thankful chair John Gurr has been encouraged by recent events, saying: #We have had three successful meetings in the past month # the A task force meeting where there were unanimous calls for Transport Scotland to decide on a solution the meeting with Iain Stewart in Inveraray and now with Jenny Gilruth.#We have had great support from all of the MSPs in our region to get these meetings to hold the government and Transport Scotland to account for their failure to deliver a safe solution in an effective timescale.#[Argyll and Bute MSP] Jenni Minto has agreed to speak to the Transport Minister to follow up on what can be done to speed up the decision on a solution and its delivery at the Rest and we look forward to hearing from her in the next few weeks.#

title: two down just 147 pylons to go
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowThe second phase of a major project to upgrade the power line between Inveraray and Crossaig is well underway as the first two pylons are erected near Lochgilphead.After completion of the stretch from Inveraray to Port Ann in July , work is proceeding on  steel towers to carry the replacement overhead line which will run  miles between Lochgilphead and Crossaig substation on the north east Kintyre coast.Teams working on SSEN Transmission’s multi-million-pound scheme are also creating  miles of access track and forming  of the tower foundations as part of the ongoing project.The new line will replace the existing infrastructure, built in the s and now reaching the end of its operating le.The replacement power line will provide a robust and reliable transmission network across the region and will serve as one of the main arteries in the west of Scotland.The line will operate at kV, with the capacity to be upgraded to kV in the future, forming a key part of SSEN Transmission’s Argyll kV strategy.This will see the electricity transmission network in the region reinforced to enable the connection of over  MW of new renewable generation, playing a key role in the transition to net zero emissions and the fight against the climate emergency.David Auld, project manager for SSEN Transmission, said: #This is a major milestone in our ongoing project between Port Ann and Crossaig, and I’m delighted to see the first of  towers installed as part of this highly complex engineering project.#As a stakeholder-led business we#ve been working closely with the local community and stakeholders to share information with them about the project and to help mitigate the impacts of our activities, and we thank them for their continued patience and understanding as we deliver this critical national infrastructure which will serve the region for many decades to come.#

title: unconfirmed-reports-serious-injury-kelso-races
story: UPDATE: JOCKEY Conner McCann required medical attention following a fall at the second flight in the mf handicap hurdle at Kelso this afternoon.He was riding Diamond State.McCann was attended to by medical staff on the course.The air ambulance arrived shortly after pm.It is now understood that Conner left the race ground in a vehicle ambulance and not the air ambulance.Racing has now resumed.More to follow:

title: jockey-regains-consciousness-asks-whether-horse-ok
story: A TEENAGE jockey’s first words after regaining consciousness following an horric fall at Kelso races on Saturday  were to enquire for the welfare of his horse.Conner McCannfell at the second jump while riding Diamond State and was treated on the track.The teenager who has gained four wins from just  rides over jumps, had only just ed to action the previous day at Musselburgh having been out injured since January.An air ambulance was called and arrived shortly after pm. After assessment he was taken to hospital in a vehicle ambulance.He is currently in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh with two broken ribs, three fractures in his thoracic vertebrae and a suspected fracture in his c vertebrae along with a tiny fracture of his fibula. Thankfully there was no sign of any head injury.His first words on regaining consciousness were: “How’s Diamond  Is my horse OK  Are you sure he’s OK ”⭕️ There were y delays to racing at Kelso today as conditional jockey Conner McCann required medical attention following a fall— Racing PostMarch , Hundreds of followers took to social media to wish him a speedy recovery.Kelso Racecourse tweeted: “We have our fingers crossed that Conner is okay and we are all sending our very best wishes.”Racing TV tweeted: “Sending our very best wishes to Conner McCann, who is conscious and being taken to hospital for further assessment after his fall at @KelsoRacecourse.”

title: tour-britain-road-cycling-event-returns-scottish-borders-year
story: WORLD-CLASS road cycling willto the Scottish Borders this year when the area hosts the prestigious Tour of Britain and Tour Series events.Galashiels will welcome Britain’s leading male and female cyclists when it hosts the Tour Series, the fun, free and family-friendly cycling event, on Wednesday  May.Launched in , the series sees Britain’s best male and female riders compete against each other in a unique, team-based format as part of a full day of sporting and community-focused activities.British sporting heroes Laura Kenny, Tom Pidcock, Dani Rowe, Joanna Rowsell, Ed Clancy, Elinor Barker and Katie Archibald have all competed in the series during its history.Gala will become the sixth Scottish host venue with this new-for- round taking place on a technical circuit that starts and finishes adjacent to the idyllic Bank Street gardens.Riders will also pass by the Burgh Chambers and War Memorial, and the Great Tapestry of Scotland Visitor Centre during the one-kilometrelap that twists its way through the town.Stage two of the Tour of Britain – the UK’s most prestigious cycle race – will then take place solely within the Scottish Borders on Monday  September.The Borders have previously welcomed the race on eight occasions, including a stage start in Hawick last year, as well as a stage that started and finished in Kelso in .Mick Bennett, Tour of Britain and Tour Series race director said: “Few places lend themselves more to cycling than the Scottish Borders, owing to the mix of historic, unforgettable towns and stunning countryside roads. To be able to take the Tour Series there for the first time andwith the Tour of Britain once again shows the appetite for our world-famous events in the area. My gratitude goes out to everybody at the Scottish Borders Council for their continued support, dedication and passion.”Sam Smith, Scottish Borders Council’s Chief Officer for Economic Development added: “We are delighted to be able to bring back the Tour of Britain to the Borders again this year, and to be hosting a round of the televised Tour Series for the first time too..remove“These will be fantastic occasions for the area and will bring in visitors and provide great exposure for the Borders, further strengthening our position as Scotland’s leading cycling destination.“I’d like to thank our partners Live Borders and Energise Galashiels for their support in bringing the Tour Series to Galashiels and their commitment to help make it an amazing event for the community and visitors.”Highlights of both the men’s and women’s Tour Series races will once again be broadcast on ITV.

title: scottish-governments-yours-use-kids-go-free-weekend
story: THIS weekendchildren between the ages of  and  will be able travel anywhere in the country for free, enabling families to adventure away from home and spend some quality time together this Easter break.The initiative is being funded by the Scottish Government to mark the historic change for ScotRail and ensuring that in its first weekend of operation as a public railway, ScotRail’s focus is firmly on future generations of rail passengers.The ‘Yours to Use’ Kids Go Free weekend will allow families to discover the joy of train travel, giving them a chance to set off and explore new places. With the offer, up to four children can travel for free with each fare-paying adult, encouraging more families to travel on Scotland’s tracks and discover the country’s hidden gems.Along with enabling children, parents, and carers to rediscover their sense of adventure, the offer hopes to persuade families to consider more sustainable forms of travel and leaving the car at home. ScotRail is committed to achieving net zero by  and is cutting carbon emissions by more than , tonnes a year - equivalent to removing , cars from the road every year.Scotrail Jenny Gilruth, Minister for Transport, said: “From  April Scotland’s Railways come into public ownership – as le begins toto normal, we want to do all we can to make rail an attractive choice for everyone - that includes families and friends looking to enjoy time together over the Easter holidays.“This offer is an early taste of the passenger focused approach we will be taking to support leisure travel as we move ScotRail forward under public control. I’d encourage as many people as possible to get out and about and enjoy all that Scotland’s Railway has to offer by taking advantage of our ‘’Yours to Use’ Kids Go Free weekend.”Lesley Kane, ScotRail Commercial Director, said: “Le is busy, especially when kids are involved, so we are delighted to be able to play our part in helping families make the most of the Easter break together by offering a ‘Kids Go Free’ weekend..remove“There’s a lot to be said about travelling by train with the family. From the excitement of exploring new places, to the journey itself, there’s certainly plenty to keep kids entertained. It also means parents get a chance to relax with less time spent behind the wheel.“We hope this offer encourages families to get onboard, enjoy a little escape this weekend, and spend some quality time together.”The ‘Yours to Use’ Kids Go Free offer can be redeemed alongside most adult tickets until Sunday,  April by simply downloading a voucher from the www.scotrail kidsgofree.Children must be accompanied by a fare-paying adult. Under s are already eligible for free train travel.Terms and conditions apply.

title: man-drove-borders-disqualified-alcohol-limit
story: BACKGROUND reports have been ordered into a -year-old man who admitted driving while disqualied and more than three times the legal alcohol limit.Ryan Bell pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to the offences which happened in the towns Bannerfield Drive and Bridge Street on May  last year.He was found to have a breath alcohol count of  microgrammes – the legal limit being .:Borders man pleads guilty to having sex with -year-old girlThe court heard that Bell had previous convictions for driving while disqualied and served a seven-month prison sentence although that post-dated the Selkirk offence. He had also been banned from driving for  months in .Sherf Peter Paterson imposed an interim disqualication and deferred sentence for a Criminal Justice Social Work Report "to seethere was an alternative to a prison sentence".Bell, of Durham, will be sentenced on April .

title: borders-college-students-aim-become-effective-global-citizens
story: A GROUP of students from Borders College will be jetting off to Toronto in May as part of the College International Programme which supports students to become effective global citizens.The students applied in December to take part in the trip and were selected following interviews in January. Since then, it has been all systems go to book flights, arrange passports and accommodation, plan transport and excursions and arrange the courses the students will undertake while they are there.Carly Forrest one of the students selected for the trip said: “Toronto is widely known for its culture and ersity, and I would love to immerse myself fully into this. Learning about new cuisines opens up a new world of ingredients and culinary adventures that I would be so excited to delve in to.“From the famous Poutine, Saskatoon Berry Pie, to Nanaimo Bars and even Taffy-On-The Snow. It would be a wonderful experience to help enhance my network and build invaluable relationships with people from all over the world. Reflecting on my own self-development, this once in a letime chance would expand my confidence immensely.”The group will visit Centennial College, a community college in Toronto offering a wide iety of courses across a range of subjects including business, communications, health, science, engineering, arts, hospitality and transportation.The college has a large number of international students and began working with Borders College in April last year to develop a short programme for our students.The group will attend college classes for two weeks during the visit with each student taking part in a course focussing on their area of interest – culinary skills, patisserie and front of house. There will be plenty of time for sightseeing though and the group have planned trips to Niagara Falls, Cirque du Soleil and to see the Toronto Blue Jays so far. Student Steven Birney described the trip, saying“This is a great opportunity for me to be pushed out of my comfort zone by going to a dferent country and doing work over there.”.removeThe trip is funded through the Turing Scheme which replaced Erasmus this year for international programmes. The college hopes to extend this for   and apply for further funding to expand the international offer.

title: uefas-revised-champions-league-qualification-plans-fair-add-value---eca
story: A revised proposal to admit two teams to the Champions League who miss out on regular qualication based on their historic performance is “fair” and “adds value”, according to one of the vice-chairman of the European Club Association.Original plans for the new European competition formats from , which were approved by UEFA’s executive committee in the hours after the Super League launched last April, included two places in the -team Champions League group phase for sides based on their UEFA co-efficient ranking.A club’s co-efficient is based on performance in Europe over the previous five seasons, and it was proposed that the top two clubs in that table who had missed out on the Champions League via domestic position would enter the group phase, so long as those clubs had done enough to qualy for one of the lesser club competitions.👉 Association club coefficients are based on the results of each countrys clubs in the five previous #UCLand #UELseasons.Rankings determine the number of places allocated to an association in forthcoming UEFA club competitions.You can find out more on the link above! pic LBVaAFue— UEFAJuly , That could have led to Manchester United, for example, finishing sixth or seventh and leapfrogging a Premier League rival into the continent’s premier competition.Europe’s top leagues, including all the clubs in the Premier League, had been understood to be opposed to the potential for leapfrogging. The European Leagues umbrella group, which includes the Premier League, and fans’ organisations insist qualication has to be earned on the pitch.UEFA has now tweaked the proposal, so that the co-efficient places must be awarded only to clubs who have finished immediately outside the Champions League qualication places in their country – so fth in the Premier League.ECA vice-chairman and UEFA club competitions committee member Aki Riihilahti believes the new proposal strikes the right balance..removevw,vw,px, px"Former Crystal Palace defender Aki Riihilahti, now a vice-chairman of the ECA, has welcomed the revised UEFA proposal “Referring to the European performancespots, I think when you add domestic performance to it, which we did, you have to look for the whole picture – how do we actually have the quality competitions, the premium competitions and then the inclusion,” the former Crystal Palace player, now chief executive of Finnish club HJK Helsinki, said at a press conference following the ECA’s General Assembly in Vienna on Tuesday.“So now, when we add domestic performance, so that the next bestis there, so that there’s no leapfrogging, it’s fair.“It adds value, and overallyou look at the total picture, it makes sense. So asa smaller country champion I was very OK with the whole thing.”It is understood the Premier League is encouraged to see UEFA moving away from the original proposal on co-efficient places, and that it intends to work closely with all stakeholders to review any new proposals in the next stage of the process.teams in the group phase instead of .One group instead of eight.matches per team instead of six.Top eight qualy for the last , the teams finishing th to th to play off for the final eight spots.The new Champions League format, set to come into effect for the - season, would feature  teams instead of the current  all playing in one league.The format signed off last April involved each team playing  matches under the so-called ‘Swiss system’, with the top eight qualying for the last  knockout stage by right and the next  clubs in the table playing off for the remaining eight slots.Riihilahti believes the proposals are an improvement on the current situation for UEFA associations ranked th downwards.There would be a minimum of  domestic champions represented across the group stages of the three European competitions – the Champions League, Europa League and the Europa Conference League, which is in its inaugural season.Runners-up from a minimum of  countries would also have a chance of Europa League qualication, where before they could only qualy for the Conference League..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: UEFA us revised Champions League qualication plans  ufair u and  uadd value u  u ECA

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as “a real dream come true”.She said: “We are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.”Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk – The Cheese Lady – has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: “We needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.“We want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.“Also, I’m hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.”Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: “Whoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That’s fantastic.“And it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.”Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: “I think we are in a good place.“When we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!”

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than £,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: “We are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.“Mary has raised a fantastic £, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.”Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised £, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman’s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: “This year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.“I’m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!”People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: zans-wildlife-diary-owls-stunning-return
story: Two winters have passed and I have not seen the owls since. I had slowly started to think that it was a once-in-a-letime opportunity until fortune smiled upon me one more time.About two weeks ago, I had a busy day at work. To recharge my batteries, I decided to go on a quick walk with the camera.Short-eared owl. Image: Zan BlaszczykAs soon as I left the house, the weather changed its course and the sky was shortly covered by nimbus clouds. Normally I wouldhome and grab my raincoat, but I did not want to waste time.When I arrived at the local reserve, the first rain droplets fell on the ground and the place became deserted. I took a wander and soon spotted a familiar flight pattern above the marshes. Upon checking through my camera, I confirmed it was a short-eared owl.The bird was flying low and patrolling the ground for voles. It even managed to catch one but it was tricky to get a good-quality photo due to the distance between us. The bird flew past me on a couple of occasions but the weather was getting worse with every minute so I headed back home. The word about the owl must have spread, as when I ed two days later, I met other fellow photographers looking for the stunning bird.I ed to the same spot as previously and sat on a rock and waited patiently. Shortly afterwards, a graceful owl with a wingspan of around cm appeared on the horizon. Without changing my position, I started following the bird with the camera. Imagine my surprise when the owl flew over me and looked straight at the camera! I silently shouted to myself: “Wow!”As soon as the owl flew behind me, I slowly turned back and spotted the second bird. Both owls were flying towards each other and, as they met halfway, they started their ‘sky dance’.The male began to rise in the sky whilst performing a combination of dynamic wing beats and gliding down, then rising again. He also made several squeaky calls accompanied by dynamic wing claps at high speeds! After repeating the whole sequence a few times, he started falling from the sky. The female joined in and they started going at each other: the birds were e-bombing one another and attacking with their talons. That aerial display lasted for about  minutes until the birds separated. What a scene it was!Courtship behaviour is spectacular for this species: often, two birds will lock their talons and, whilst holding onto each other, they will start tumbling nearly to the ground before letting go.I encourage everyone who has a chance to observe this behaviour, as this is a ‘must’ in the birding world. It is worth remembering, though, that this species is sensitive to disturbance and their numbers are considered declining during the past two decades. It is crucial not to approach the owls or their nesting site. For your observation, I would recommend choosing one spot and remaining there. This way, you have a chance to show them that you are no threat to them and hopefully the owls will get used to your presence. I prefer this technique rather than hiding as, considering owls’ excellent eyesight, it is almost impossible to stay unnoticed. By waiting at the same position, we can also eliminate another factor, which is chasing off their prey: as we walk, the ground shakes under our feet and small mammals, such as mice or voles which the owls feed on, will disappear. Short-eared owls like marshy and boggy places, so it is important not to walk over the rich habitat but use paths.www.zanslenswww.facebook zanslenswww zans_lensIf you have owls living in your backyard or would like me to photograph and feature wildle from your area, please get in touch!

title: brunton-musselburgh-children-star-bugsy-malone
story: Youth acting group Drama Mill auditioned  children for the show, and now has a cast of  children from North Berwick, Aberlady, Gullane, Cockenzie and Haddington, aged from eight to .Linda Kearsley Ross, Drama Mill director, said that the performance – the group’s first foray into musical theatre – was “ambitious” but that the children had loved taking on the roles of s New York gangsters.County children to star in Bugsy MaloneShe added: “Bugsy Malone was our first choice of play.“Drama facilitators Claudia Overton and Stephanie Wynne and I have all taken part in productions when we were at school and have fond memories of performing this play.“It’s ambitious to do it with such a young castbut our fabulous talented group have risen to the task.“This is the first time we have performed at The Brunton and we are so excited to give our youngsters the opportunity to perform on a professional stage.”The cast will perform the famous musical numbers accompanied by a live nine-piece band, whose members are all volunteering their time and talent.Drama faclitator Stephanie Wynne coaches the young Bugsy Malone castAnd the production will emulate the original  film, starring Jodie Foster, by using splurge guns and foam pies.Linda said: “There is something really fun about playing gangsters and molls, and using splurge to take people down rather than bullets.“Some people criticised that the ending is really abrupt, i.e. that they all become friends and sing a song, but I don’t think children question the ending – they believe bad people can become good people and that, as the words say, ‘ you give a little love then it all comes back to you’.”Tickets can be bought via    or thebrunton en-GB shows bugsy%malone events - Bugsy Malone is on at The Brunton on March  .

title: pear-tree-nursery-gets-approval-changes-west-road-premises
story: The Pear Tree Nursery, on Haddington’s West Road, was given approval for advertisements at the front of the Category B listed building.The business was also given the green light to create a toilet which could be accessed at the rear of the building.The Architectural Heritage Society of Scotland claimed the height and positioning of the signage meant it “visually intrudes on the main façade of the listed building and the wider conservation area”.The group also felt the works had “no architectural merit and are not in keeping with the listed building”.However, East Lothian Council’s planning department granted permission with the condition that the advertising consent expires in March .

title: chance-boost-fitness-levels-couch-5k
story: The initiative starts on Wednesday, April , with a gentle introduction by trained jog leaders.It is aimed at people who want to try running for the first time, others who might want to take it up again after injury or illness, or those who simply want to get more exercise.Charles Stable, the club’s vice-chairman, said: “The programme has been made possible with the support of East Lothian Sports Hub, who have assisted greatly with the funding for training our jog leaders.”He added: “Many of the runners who start with the Couch to k programme gain confidence to keep on running and take on and achieve many personal running challenges.“The -week course culminated in completing a local parkrun supported by members of Musselburgh and District Athletics Club.”A drop-in information event will be held at Fisherrow Yacht Club in New Street, Musselburgh, on Wednesday, March , when anyone interested in getting involved can meet the jog leaders from .pm to .pm.For more information, visit musselburghac jogscotland-musselburgh

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-march-24-28-1997-1972-1922
story: ‘BOSNIANS say thank you for help’, reported the East Lothian Courier on March , .A group of Bosnians , who found safety in East Lothian after escaping the civil war in the former Yugoslavia, have shown their appreciation of the man who brought them to Scotland and helped them build a new le.Eddie Carmichael, formerly of the Bosnian Project Team, was presented with an engraved wrist watch as a ‘thank you’ for his help, from a group of Bosnians living in Haddington and Dunbar.Jasmin Kilic, one of those forced to leave the country, spoke of his gratitude to Mr Carmichael.“We came to Scotland from Croatia in March  and Eddie was our co-ordinator and helped us find homes, schools and also brought together a lot of families that had been split up by the war,” he said....and  years ago‘COUNCIL objects to strip shows in pubs’ was a headline in the East Lothian Courier of March , .An objection to striptease shows being held in licensed premises was made by Cockenzie and Port Seton Town Council to East Lothian Licensing Court on Tuesday.In a letter to the court, the Town Clerk, Mr T. Walker said: “I have been instructed by my Council to write objecting to the striptease show which my Council understand was held recently in the Port Seton Hotel.“It is understood this was a private show and that admittance was by ticket only. Nevertheless my Council are very strongly of the opinion that this is not the type of show which should be held on licensed premises and I have been asked to request the court to consider this matter when dealing with the renewal of the certicate for the hotel.”...and  years agoA DISTURBANCE by a soldier in East Linton was described by The Haddingtonshire Courier on March , .On Monday, in Haddington Sherf Court, James Michael Collins, private in the H.L.I., East Fortune, pleaded guilty to having, on Saturday, committed a breach of the peace at the Red Lion Hotel, East Linton, and on the public road, and subsequently broken a pane of glass in a window in the police station.It was stated that the accused and another soldier had been refused a drink at the hotel, owing to their intoxicated condition.They ed, and, on again being refused, committed a disturbance.

title: 150k-funding-donated-help-over-50s-keep-active
story: Shine Public Health has been awarded £, of UK Research and Innovationfunding as part of the Healthy Ageing Challenge.The project is Shine’s first large-scale trial, supporting over-s across East Lothian.The Haddington-based social enterprise company aims to connect everyone with physical activities they will enjoy and keep enjoying.The company has developed an app, Shine, that is designed to help community-based health campaigns increase levels of physical activity, improving quality of le and drastically reducing long-term healthcare costs.Dr Joanna Smail, GP partner at Tranent Medical Practice, backed the social enterprise’s aims.She said: “We know first-hand that increasingly large sums of money are being spent on expensive drugs to treat conditions which could be prevented and managed with lestyle change.“As a GP, I wholeheartedly support Shine in their mission to increase physical activity provision, getting people more active and transforming lives.”Physical inactivity is one of the leading causes of premature death.Small increases in activity, particularly for older people, can help prevent and manage long-term conditions.Shine aims to help people get more active, in a way that is right for them, removing barriers to participation, supporting changes in behaviour and encouraging healthy habits.The -month project got under way this month and will involve testing the app with a range of activity providers and classes for over-s across East Lothian.Research and evaluation carried out by the University of Stirling will test Shine’s ability to deliver lasting behavioural change.Councillor John McMillan, Provost of East Lothian, said: “Shine provides a fantastic opportunity for local groups to be rewarded for the incredible support and encouragement they provide, improving the health and wellbeing of our community.”Shine welcomes any activity provider within East Lothian to sign up.They will receive a share of £,, plus help to improve their online promotion and hopefully an increase in membership.

title: travelodge-ranks-top-10-uk-landmarks-visit-spring---see
story: The hotel chain has been gearing up for the Easter break by slashing the prices of its rooms and rounding up the best spots you can visit on your Spring staycation."When we think of places wed love to visit in our letime, our mind often wanders to faraway places across the globe. Its easy to forget that we have an abundance of incredible landmarks right here in the UK," Travelodge said.The company added: "We have handpicked a selection that we think should be on your list to visit this spring, from castles to cathedrals and everything in between!"York Minster. Credit: PA Here are the top ten UK landmarks that should be on your to-visit list this Spring, according to Travelodge.Shop the best deals to stay nearby these popular tourist spots this year via the Travelodge website.: TripAdvisor reveals the top British Spring destinations : Tripadvisor reveals best international destinations for Spring - See the top Blackpool Tower. Credit: PA It is now easier than ever to plan your ultimate Easter staycation without blowing the budget.The hotel chain has slashed the price of , rooms across its  locations.You can access the £ room deal now on stays between Friday, April  and Sunday, April , .The offer is subject to some terms and conditions including that all rates are subject to availability at the time of booking.It may also not be available at every hotel, every night.If youre booking a stay for a family of four  a £ room works out at just £ per person.A night away is already working out cheaper than a trip to your local cinema and could open doors to a spot youve not explored together before.See all the terms and conditions and book your bargain stay via the Travelodge website.

title: top-10-experiences-brits-want-receive-birthday-gift-according-buyagift
story: Gt experience provider, Buyagt, conducted some research and found that % of Brits would prefer to receive an experience rather than a physical gt for their birthday.The list includes a iety of experiences including spa breaks, a trip to the theatre and afternoon tea.The research suggests that the most popular experience Brits would like to receive on their birthday is a short hotel break while the least popular is the Segway experience." alt"East Lothian Courier: A helicopter " class"editor-image"A helicopterSo,you’re looking for gt inspiration for a loved one, take a look at the list of the top  experiences Brits want to receive on their birthday.If you know someone who would appreciate a relaxing break, buying a short hotel break or spa day would be the ideal gt to buy for them. You can find spa days and hotel breaks via the Buyagt website.Alternatively,you’re looking for the perfect gt for the person who loves to indulge in some tasty food or go for a trip to the theatre, you can find more experiences via the Buyagt website.You can view the full range of experiences available for gting via the Buyagt website.

title: familys-bid-new-home-garden
story: Plans for a three-bedroom bungalow in the gardens of Manor House, Belhaven, have been lodged with East Lothian Council’s planning department.The revised proposals come after similar plans were withdrawn earlier this month.A design and access statement included with Teena Gilmour’s proposals noted the family connection to the house.It read: “The client and her family have lived in the Manor House for the last  years, and it is hoped that the proposed new dwelling in the garden grounds will allow Mrs Gilmour to do so for a lot longer with a more suitable single level modern home that will meet her needs.“The Manor House will remain in the family to be utilised by Mrs Gilmour’s son and his young family and will continue to be a family home.”According to the agents representing Mrs Gilmour, the siting of the property would provide both the client and neighbouring properties with “a great deal of privacy”.

title: path-linking-tyninghame-binning-wood-gets-go-ahead
story: Discussions about finding a route to connect the village and the nearby beauty spot have been ongoing for a number of years.Now, a step forward has been taken, with a short section of path beside Tyninghame’s schoolhouse approved.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council told the Courier it was still too early to give an indication as to when the path would be created.She said: “This is a footpath from Tyninghame village to an existing core path and for the next stage the council hopes to work with the landowner to explore funding options for the remainder of a path up to Binning Wood.”East Lothian Council undertook a number of public consultations between  and  as part of the development of its core paths plan.At that time, a route was proposed to connect Tyninghame to Binning Wood.Daniel Wight, from Dunpender Community Council, which covers Tyninghame, previously highlighted the importance of a path.He said: “As long as we’ve been here, there has been frustration that there is no way of getting from the village to Binning Wood, which is a major recreational destination for walkers and particularly dog walkers.“There is no way of getting there safely other than getting in a car and driving up, which is crazy – it is less than a mile away.”Under the plans, a poplar tree will be removed.The planning officer’s report reads: “The proposed whindust path would provide a link to an existing path.“The formalising of the informal footpath would facilitate rural recreation in the area.”

title: veterans-urge-people-get-bikes-raise-money-poppyscotland
story: Jack Regan, , who served in Iraq and recently retired as a ScottishPower linesman, united with former artilleryman Billy Morrison, from Musselburgh, to urge cyclists of all ages and abilities to join the seventh annual cycling fundraiser event, which takes place in East Lothian.Jack, who served alongside Billy in Iraq, said: “This is a fantastic day out, as well as a way to show our support to former servicemen and women and their families.“Veterans can be very reluctant to ask for help, but we want to get the message out that it’s only a phone call away.”Billy, , has already cycled  miles for Poppyscotland and raised £, as part of his  Poppy Pledge.He cycled the distance of Land’s End to John O’Groats around East Lothian and on a static bike in the Musselburgh Tesco store in the run-up to Remembrance Sunday last year.Returning after a two-year break, the Sportive has already raised more than £, to support current and former members of the armed forces and their families across the country.About , cyclists are expected to take part in the event on Sunday, September , sponsored by Fred. Olsen Renewables.Starting and finishing at Prestonpans Community Centre, three routes ranging from  to  miles will take in the coastal road to North Berwick, then loop round the East Lothian countryside.More adventurous riders will cycle over the Lammermuirs, dipping down to Chirnside and Duns in the Scottish Borders.Billy, who served in the first Gulf War and Afghanistan and now works as a Tesco delivery driver, said: “I’d encourage cyclists of all ages and abilities to join in, get fit and raise funds for a great cause.“I’ve been very lucky myself, but I see this as a way to give back to former colleagues.“Whenever I needed a bit of help, someone always stepped up for me.“That’s something I’ll always recognise and I want to make sure that everyone  who has served can get the help they need.”Gordon Michie, Poppyscotland’s head of fundraising and learning, said: “We’re very excited that the Sportive is ing to East Lothian and the Borders after a two-year break.“It’s always a sell-out event, so we are encouraging cyclists to sign up as soon as possible.“We keep numbers low to avoid the need for road closures, and the intimate and friendly feel of the event is one of its attractions.“The route takes in stunning coastal views and country roads, while the timed hill climb will challenge more experienced cyclists.“We’re incredibly grateful to Fred. Olsen Renewables for continuing to sponsor us this year.“This means  per cent of the sign-up fee and any sponsorship raised will go directly to our work supporting Scotland’s armed forces community.“We’ve already raised more than a quarter of a million pounds to provide vital welfare support to families across Scotland, from help with housing and employment to mental and physical health issues.”The Sportive is an ‘open road’ cycling event, meaning that no roads will be closed, in order to minimise disruption to the public.Participants on e-bikes and tandems are welcome to take part, while riders can have a free placethey are supporting a cyclist with a disability.Visit www.poppyscotland.org.uk sportive for more information or to register.

title: ultra-marathoner-moonwalk-charity
story: Neil Scott will line up in Edinburgh’s Holyrood Park in June as part of The MoonWalk Scotland.Hundreds of people will walk up to . miles to raise money and awareness for those living with breast cancer and other cancers.Neil, who works at the Astley Ainslie Hospital in Edinburgh, is taking on the challenge for his “wonderful mother-in-law Madge Wilson”, who was diagnosed with breast cancer shortly before the start of the coronavirus pandemic.He said: “She’s a really treasured part of our family – and quite a character – so the news came as a real shock.“Luckily her cancer journey was very straightforward.“She discovered a lump and was seen very quickly, then had really good treatment and, at the end, a positive outcome.“Madge is now almost  and one of the most caring people you could ever meet.“She’s recovered really well.”Walk the Walk’s MoonWalk Scotland is ing to the Capital for the first time since .The global pandemic had seen the gathering shelved but organisers are looking forward to walkers setting off at midnight on June .Those taking part are given a bra, which can be decorated, as well as a t-shirt with a bra pictured on it.Neil, who is secretary and a jog leader at Haddington Running Club, is no stranger to covering large distances and will be taking on the Full Moon – . miles.However, the dad-of-two, who will be joined in his training by good friend Margaret MacLeod, was sure the walk would prove dferent from his usual challenges.Neil, who lives in Haddington, said: “At the age of , this will be my very first walking marathon – I’m normally a runner and have completed a number of ultra marathons!“I know that walking will be a totally dferent experience from what I’m used to and it will be a real challenge for me.“I’ll be following the special training plan which Walk the Walk sends and I’m planning to get out on a number of long walks with Margaret.“I originally signed up for The MoonWalk Scotland in , but the event was postponed due to the pandemic and I can’t wait to get to the starting line.“I’m very proud to be taking part as a man – not everyone is aware that men can do The MoonWalk. And, after all, men do get breast cancer too.“I won’t put pressure on myself on the night – I just want to enjoy it!”To sponsor Neil, go to walk thewalk.enthuse pf neil-scott

title: view-vocalist-headline-family-friendly-music-festival-musselburgh
story: The National Trust for Scotlands visitor attraction will host Festhailes on Saturday, May , starring a line-up of Scottish acts, headlined by Kyle Falconer, lead vocalist of The View.Other acts set to perform are: Daniel Meade and The Basement Boogiemen Blue Rose Code Mark Sharp and the Bicycle Thieves The Ronains and Have Mercy Las Vegas.Claire Grant, the trusts Edinburgh operations manager, said: "We can’t wait to welcome visitors to enjoy Scottish music acts in the beautul grounds of Newhailes."Everyone is welcome at this family-friendly event – so come along and enjoy the music."Newhailes is hosting the festivalFesthailes will run from pm to pm and include face-painting, child-friendly fairground rides and food and drink provided by vintage food trucks.Taking place on the lawn in front of the mansion, young festival-goers will also be able to play in the newly expanded Weehailes adventure playground.Tickets are going fast, with more than  per cent already sold.Go to eventbrite e festhailes-tickets- to book.

title: postman-sacked-leaving-chewing-gum-garden-ornament-wins-17-000
story: Former Dundee football player Graham Harvey spent  years working for the mailing company and was based at its Prestonpans office on Ayres Wynd when his contract was terminated for gross misconduct in .The postman, who was  at the time, was caught by the homeowner, who complained to his bosses and handed over CCTV evidence of the incident, which also captured the worker driving without a seat belt and leaving his Royal Mail van unlocked.Late last year, an employment tribunal heard that Mr Harvey was unfairly dismissed and he has since been granted £,. in compensation for being fired.The judgement of the tribunal awarded £,. relating to the period November , , to November , , and the monetary award exceeds the prescribed element by £,..The hearing was told that in October , a customer visited the Prestonpans office to complain about the chewing gum incident.The customer also emailed CCTV footage to the office alongside a photograph and written complaint, describing the conduct as “disgusting”.But the customer also claimed he and his we “did not wish to make a huge fuss about it”.When Mr Harvey ed to work the next week, he was brought in for a talk with Jordan Cree, the delivery office manager for the office, in which he admitted to driving without a seatbelt and leaving  items of mail on his passenger seat but denied placing the chewing gum on the customer’s premises – he later admitted to lying about the gum.The tribunal heard that he was suspended at the end of the meeting pending “further investigations into an alleged incident where you have defaced a customer’s property”.A disciplinary meeting was held, at which Mr Harvey admitted all of the allegations against him.He described the chewing gum incident as a “stupid decision” and said he had done it “on two occasions at most”, while offering to apologise directly to the customer.He also admitted driving without a seatbelt in rural locations.

title: libraries-temporarily-closed-due-staff-absences
story: Staff shortages mean some of East Lothian’s libraries are operating on reduced hours this week.Ormiston Library was closed yesterday , while Gullane and East Linton’s libraries are closed today .Ormiston Library will again be closed tomorrowwhile Port Seton Library is shut on Thursday.The Port Seton Centre will close early at pm today and will shut at pm on Thursday and .pm on Friday.The café is closed to the public all week.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: “We are grateful to users for their patience and understanding at this dficult time.“We hope to resume normal service as quickly as possible.”The Courier had askedthe staff shortages were related to the coronavirus pandemic.The spokesperson added: “While COVID-related issues are continuing to present dficulties to council resources and staffing challenges there are dferent types of staff absence being experienced, as well as some vacancies we are hoping to fill.”

title: wordle-279-march-25-wordle-word-hints-todays-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you’re still trying to save your streak, then don’t scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today’s word starts with the letter D and ends with the letter T.It has two vowelsThis word can describe a place for storage.What is today’s Wordle answer, Friday, March  If you have given up on today’s game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now. The Wordle for March  is DEPOT. The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: “Since launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.“The game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .“It has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me – from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.“On the flip side, I’d be lyingI said this hasn’t been overwhelming.“After all, I am just one person, and it is important to me that, as Wordle grows, it continues to provide a great experience to everyone.“Given this, I am incredibly pleased to announce that I’ve reached an agreement with The New York Times for them to take over running Wordle going forward.”
