title: uefas-revised-champions-league-qualification-plans-fair-add-value---eca
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.A revised proposal to admit two teams to the Champions League who miss out on regular qualication based on their historic performance is “fair” and “adds value”, according to one of the vice-chairman of the European Club Association.Original plans for the new European competition formats from , which were approved by UEFA’s executive committee in the hours after the Super League launched last April, included two places in the -team Champions League group phase for sides based on their UEFA co-efficient ranking.A club’s co-efficient is based on performance in Europe over the previous five seasons, and it was proposed that the top two clubs in that table who had missed out on the Champions League via domestic position would enter the group phase, so long as those clubs had done enough to qualy for one of the lesser club competitions.👉 Association club coefficients are based on the results of each countrys clubs in the five previous #UCL and #UEL seasons.Rankings determine the number of places allocated to an association in forthcoming UEFA club competitions.You can find out more on the link above! pic LBVaAFue— UEFAJuly , That could have led to Manchester United, for example, finishing sixth or seventh and leapfrogging a Premier League rival into the continent’s premier competition.Europe’s top leagues, including all the clubs in the Premier League, had been understood to be opposed to the potential for leapfrogging. The European Leagues umbrella group, which includes the Premier League, and fans’ organisations insist qualication has to be earned on the pitch.UEFA has now tweaked the proposal, so that the co-efficient places must be awarded only to clubs who have finished immediately outside the Champions League qualication places in their country – so fth in the Premier League.ECA vice-chairman and UEFA club competitions committee member Aki Riihilahti believes the new proposal strikes the right balance. vw,vw,px, px"Former Crystal Palace defender Aki Riihilahti, now a vice-chairman of the ECA, has welcomed the revised UEFA proposal “Referring to the European performancespots, I think when you add domestic performance to it, which we did, you have to look for the whole picture – how do we actually have the quality competitions, the premium competitions and then the inclusion,” the former Crystal Palace player, now chief executive of Finnish club HJK Helsinki, said at a press conference following the ECA’s General Assembly in Vienna on Tuesday.“So now, when we add domestic performance, so that the next bestis there, so that there’s no leapfrogging, it’s fair.“It adds value, and overallyou look at the total picture, it makes sense. So asa smaller country champion I was very OK with the whole thing.”It is understood the Premier League is encouraged to see UEFA moving away from the original proposal on co-efficient places, and that it intends to work closely with all stakeholders to review any new proposals in the next stage of the process.The new Champions League format, set to come into effect for the - season, would feature  teams instead of the current  all playing in one league.The format signed off last April involved each team playing  matches under the so-called ‘Swiss system’, with the top eight qualying for the last  knockout stage by right and the next  clubs in the table playing off for the remaining eight slots.Riihilahti believes the proposals are an improvement on the current situation for UEFA associations ranked th downwards.There would be a minimum of  domestic champions represented across the group stages of the three European competitions – the Champions League, Europa League and the Europa Conference League, which is in its inaugural season.Runners-up from a minimum of  countries would also have a chance of Europa League qualication, where before they could only qualy for the Conference League.

title: queen-senior-royals-gather-together-moving-remembrance-philip
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.The Queen has rallied to join close family, friends, foreign royals and hundreds of charity workers in remembrance of her beloved husband the Duke of Edinburgh at a poignant memorial service.Front and centre of the high profile occasion was the Duke of York, despite Andrew paying millions out of court earlier this month to settle a civil sexual assault case.Andrew, in his first public appearance since the settlement to his accuser Virginia Giuffre, escorted his mother into Westminster Abbey.The monarch held onto Andrew’s elbow with her left hand as she moved slowly and gingerly to her place, using a walking stick in her right hand.They entered via Poets Corner – a shorter route for the Queen’s comfort – in a small procession. vw,vw,px, px"The Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall arrive at Westminster Abbey The monarch’s state limousine had arrived at Poets’ Yard entrance with Andrew sat beside her after they travelled from Windsor together.Inside the abbey, they walked at a slow but steady pace, both looking ahead, and at the end of the aisle they separated – with Andrew giving a last glance to his mother as she turned right.As the service began, the Prince of Wales leaned over to the Queen and spoke to her briefly. vw,vw,px, px"The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, Prince George and Princess Charlotte also attended The Queen delved into her black Launer handbag for her glasses.Andrew, who stepped down from public le over his friendship with convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein, had a front row seat, sitting next to his brother the Earl of Wessex and across the aisle from his other siblings.Among those attending were Charles, the Duchess of Cornwall, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, the Countess of Wessex, the Princess Royal, Princess Beatrice and Princess Eugenie.Prince George and Princess Charlotte were also present in honour of their great-grandfather – the first time they have attended a major public church service.Some , people packed the gothic church – in marked contrast to Philip’s funeral where only  were permitted to attend amid Covid restrictions, with the Queen sat alone, masked in mourning.The monarch, , had been determined to make the appearance at the deeply personal and signicant occasion on Tuesday in honour of her “strength and stay” Philip – with her attendance only confirmed the same morning.“So, how did I get my first job at  without any professional experience  The DofE. All the answers in my CV and interview were all related to work I had previously done with the award. Give an example of where you have shown teamwork skills – my expedition in Wales.” https:t.co DhCOgT— DofEMarch , It was the Queen’s first major official engagement outside one of her homes for nearly six months, since she travelled to Cardf to deliver a speech at the Welsh Senedd on October .The Queen listened as the Dean of Windsor paid tribute to Philip’s intellect, work ethic, sense of humour and devotion to his family.The Right Reverend David Conner described the duke as a “remarkable man” who was committed to “a host of down-to-earth enterprises”. vw,vw,px, px"The Princess Royal and Vice Admiral Sir Tim Laurence He pointed out that the duke could be “abrupt”, and suggested that at times he could forget “just how intimidating he could be”.Princess Beatrice was seen to give a small chuckle as the Dean remarked: “He could be somewhat sharp in pricking what he thought to be bubbles of pomposity or sycophancy.”The monarch, the Duchess of Cornwall and the Princess Royal were all dressed in dark green – seen as a special tribute to Philip, whose livery colour was Edinburgh Green. vw,vw,px, px"Queen Silvia and Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden, arrive at the service Others throughout the congregation also wore the shade, including Duke of Edinburgh Gold Award holder Doyin Sonibare, who delivered a special tribute about the effect Philip’s youth scheme had on her le.The Queen stopped to speak to Ms Sonibare at the end of the service, with the monarch smiling broadly as she expressed her appreciation for her speech.Ms Sonibare said “She thanked me for my speech – she was lovely, really kind. And she asked what I did for my Duke of Edinburgh’s award.”The -year-old, who has an ambassador role with the award, said: “I just got a message from my mum, she said ‘Congratulations, really proud of you’.”She added of her own green outfit: “I think it was just a crazy coincidenceI’m honest, but it’s quite nice, like we’re all in sync.”The monarch was heavily involved in arrangements for the service which featured elements Philip planned for his own funeral which were forbidden due to Covid- restrictions. vw,vw,px, px"Prince Michael of Kent and Princess Michael of Kent A rousing rendition of the hymn Guide Me, O Thou Great Redeemer – also known as Bread Of Heaven – was one of his particular requests, but congregational singing was banned at the time of his death.Eleven months on, those who knew and loved Philip sang the anthem with gusto as the song echoed around the vast church.Other missing gestures from Philip’s pre-pandemic Forth Bridge plans saw Gold Duke of Edinburgh’s Award holders and members of the youth UK Cadet Force associations line the steps of the abbey, and prayers being said by the clergy from Windsor, Sandringham and Balmoral.Elements of today’s Service will incorporate some features planned for the Funeral of The Duke of Edinburgh, which were unable to go ahead due to Covid restrictions in place at the time.Read the Order of Service 👇— The Royal FamilyMarch , Special arrangements were put in place for the Queen’s comfort, with the service limited to  minutes and the monarch sitting in one of the Canada chairs but with an additional cushion.The dficulty for the Queen, who has confessed to not being able to move, was understood to be whether the monarch would be able to walk to her seat.

title: superyacht-owned-russian-businessman-detained-london
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.A £ million superyacht has been detained in London as part of sanctions against Russia, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps has announced.UK officials boarded Phi – owned by a Russian businessman – in Canary Wharf, east London, on Tuesday.The vessel is the first to be detained in the UK under sanctions imposed because of the war in Ukraine.Phi – named after the mathematical concept – made her maiden voyage last year after being built in the Netherlands.She is bright blue and features what is described as an “infinite wine cellar” and a freshwater swimming pool.At . metres long, she is twice as long as the other boats docked around her in Canary Wharf. vw,vw,px, px"Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said the yacht would not be moving Mr Shapps told the PA news agency the ship was in London for a “refit” but “won’t be going anywhere”.He said: “It’s just another indication that we will not stand by whilst Putin’s cronies are allowed to sail around the world in these kinds of yachts and people in Ukraine are suffering.“When you see what he’s doing to Ukraine, when you see what he’s doing to people’s lives, it can’t be right to have a yacht like this here in London, able to just sail away, and that is why we’ve impounded it and denied its ability to go anywhere right now.” vw,vw,px, px"The superyacht is the first to be detained in the UK under sanctions imposed because of the war in Ukraine The vessel’s horn was sounded twice while the Cabinet minister was being interviewed.Someone thought to be a member of crew stuck a paper sign reading “PO JUSTICE FOR THE ” to the side of the boat.This comes after PO Ferries sacked nearly  seafarers without notice.The Department for Transportsaid it worked with the National Crime Agency and the Border Force Maritime Investigation Bureau to identy and detain Phi. vw,vw,px, px"The superyacht contains a swimming pool It refused to reveal the name of her owner, stating that he is “a Russian businessman”.The department described Phi’s ownership as “deliberately well hidden”.She is registered to a company based in the Caribbean dual-island nation of Saint Kitts and Nevis, and carries a Maltese flag.The DfT said it is “looking at a number of other vessels” and hopes its “strong stance sends an example to international partners”.

title: lace to compete at crufts for fifth time
story: A Sandwick woman and her seven-year-old dog will compete at Crufts in a Scottish team this week # for the fth time together.Sally Sanford and Lace, her Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever, will take part in the rally event on Thursday at the NEC in Birmingham.The pair are part of a Scotland team who will face Wales, Northern Ireland and four English regional teams in the inter-regional rally competition.The rally course sees dog and handler work as a pair to navigate a course of between  and  dferent exercises.Ms Sanford said the competition was always #a step-up#.#You#re asking the dogs to do stuff that isn#t that complicated for them, but it#s the handlers who need to be able to multi-task, to concentrate in the moment and navigate their way around the course.#You need your head in the game.#But she said that was one of Lace#s strengths, and said he had finished second in his event previously.The pair are hoping for another strong showing, but with Crufts taking place for the first time since March , she said there were some uncertainties.#None of us know how busy Crufts is going to be this year,# she said.#I would be lyingI said there wasn#t a degree of trepidation.#She said that she was excited for theof the #enormous# event, though, and hopes Lace will be able to inspire Scotland to better their previous best performance of third...Pet pooches are being given the chance to test their agility and obedience without even having to leave their own gardens – proving that lockdownSandwick resident Sally Sanford will be appearing at the Crufts dog show this week as part of the Scottish rally team with her Nova ScotiaA dog lover from Bigton says that making the final in the Kennel Club’s Eukanuba Friends for Le competition at Crufts  would mean the#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: bobby retires after 40 years keeping the water flowing
story: A water worker has been commended for his four decades of public service.The -year-old from Lerwick said the time had gone by ldquolike a flash.ldquoIrsquove worked all over Shetland, from Fair Isle to Unst but I really enjoyed working in Lerwick, working in the town, he added.ldquoTrying to find the bursts, digging them up and repairing them, that was very, very satisfying.Mr Fullerton worked in water operations from - and spent the last  years in the sampling team.Over the years he has dealt with ldquolots of bursts in strange places including getting ldquoabsolutely soaked and contending with a  foot jet of water in the centre of Lerwick.A keen motorcyclist, Mr Fullerton said he was now looking forward to having more time to spend on le outside work.ldquoIrsquom going to miss the people that you get to work with for a long time, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think there is anyone left from the days that I started which is a strange feeling but it is nice to be part of the team.Water team leader Jim Anderson said Mr Fullerton would be missed by his colleagues.ldquoHis great sense of humour and willingness to help anybody and everybody who knocked on his door for yet another lsquoquick favourrsquo will certainly not be forgotten, he added...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. Before joining The Shetland Times, I was part of Archants Investigations Unit, reporting for titles across the group. When not at work, Im usually reading books, listening to records or walking around the countryside.Scottish Water has said it will be renewing around km of water mains between Bigton and Maywick over the next year. The £.m project will#Drivers have been warned of signicant delays while repairs are carried out to a burst watermain at a busy roundabout. Three-way traffic lights have been#Scottish Water has completed an £, project to upgrade their water treatment works in Unst. title: electoral contest in south mainland assured
story: An election contest is assured in the South Mainland in May, with five candidates standing for the ward. to stand means voters in the Shetland South ward will be required to choose who will represent them in the next council.Only three candidates came forward for election in , in what was then a three-member ward.Electoral boundary changes have since meant the Shetland South area will be served by four elected members.Independent Mr Peterson will be standing against Shetland Greens candidate Alex Armitage in May#s electoral contest.Earlier this month construction industry expert Stewart Douglas announced he would also be standing.Mr Douglas last stood for council in , when he campaigned for the Shetland Central seat under an SNP ticket.But he is standing as an independent candidate this time round.Retaining the fight for the SNP will be Robbie McGregor, however, who is understood to be standing again for the SNP for the Scottish nationalists.Meanwhile, Allison Duncan is contesting for Shetland South again., the  year-old said there was #unfinished business# he wished to see done.#My main priorities are the Levenwick road refurbishment and the Fair Isle ferry # and close behind that is the water mist suppressant system to enhance safety in all our care homes in Shetland,# he said.Mr Duncan said it was a #severe disappointment# that not enough potential candidates came forward in the South Mainland in .He said standing against four other candidates #will tell meI#ve done a reasonable job, a good job, orI#m no damned use#.#This election will at least give me the answer,# he said.Mr Duncan insisted he would continue as an independent candidate.Askedhe had considered standing for the SNP, he replied: #You must be crazy to stand for that outfit.#Local writer and broadcaster Tom Morton will stand as an official Scottish Labour Party candidate in the Shetland North ward.#I believe the party#s values best represent a viable and valuable future for Shetland,# he said.#Compassion, social justice and fairness are traditional Shetland qualities, and these are the core ideals of the Scottish Labour Party.#And Shetland Central member Moraig Lyall has said she will stand again...Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. title: spaceport overcomes final hurdle to start work on historic 100m project
story: Work can finally begin on Shetlandrsquos poundm space centre after ministers confirmed they had no intention to intervene.The Scottish government told the SIC on Friday that it was able to approve the SaxaVord Spaceport as initially indicated last month.Although the council previously confirmed it was ldquominded to approve the application ndash Scottish ministers had  days to decide whether to ldquocall it in.With that threat no longer looming over the project, work can now get under way.Blasting work had already begun and shipments of stone chips arrived on site ndash but the team had been awaiting the governmentrsquos final go ahead before beginning the major work.Over the next  months the team plans to spend poundm ndash rising to poundm over five years.Despite planning delays, with approval taking almost  months, the first launch is still hoped to take place this year.It is hoped to create around  jobs in Unst and boost the islandrsquos economy by almost poundm a year. It is expected to provide a further  jobs throughout Shetland...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. Before joining The Shetland Times, I was part of Archants Investigations Unit, reporting for titles across the group. When not at work, Im usually reading books, listening to records or walking around the countryside.The global company looking to deliver the UKrsquos first vertical satellite launch has welcomed the approval of spaceport plans ndash saying ldquoall systems are go#.Work on a £m spaceport could start next month after receiving its long-awaited planning approval.The Shetland Space Centre in Unst is changing its name to SaxaVord Spaceport. title: use reserves to create investment bank greens say
story: A new investment bank could be created, using money from the council#s reserves.The idea is being developed by Shetland Greens, who wish to see at least  per cent of reserves invested locally by the end of the next council term.It follows an earlier suggestion from the party that an energy company be launched # also using money from the reserve fund.The party says loans would be made from the Shetland Investment Bank at affordable rates of interest.The aim is to spark the development of community owned renewable energy projects and support small businesses, helping to ersy Shetland#s local economy. The party says larger loans from the bank could also part-finance fixed links to Yell, Unst and Whalsay.The SIC reserve fund and pension fund are together currently valued at well over £bn, with all of this money currently invested on the international stock market.Shetland South candidate Alex Armitage said: #The global economy is in upheaval with conflict and is threatened by climate breakdown.#Many economists are predicting a recession in coming years. We have the opportunity to make more secure investments in Shetland # and that#s exactly what we should be doing with our reserves.#..Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.Shetland has shown overwhelming support for Ukraine, with a pop up shop raising almost £,.Folk should take the time to submit electricity and gas meter readings before the energy price cap rises this Friday st April, urges Shetland MP#Time is running out for would-be candidates thinking of throwing their hats in the ring for election.Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220327news200 000 pledged to support agricultural shows
story: Outgoing AgricultureMinister Edwin Pootshas announced a pound, package of support for Northern Ireland’s agricultural shows following the Covid- pandemic. Announcing the bounce back support scheme, Mr Poots said: “Many businesses and sectors were adversely affected by the Covid- pandemic, and our agricultural shows were not immune to these effects, with all shows cancelled in  and only a few being able to take place in . This resulted in shows losing the opportunity to raise vital funds that would help prepare for the  season. “Shows play a vital role in showcasing our excellent agri-food produce and supporting our rural communities, as well as boosting our economy and the additional tourism opportunities. These shows are predominately run by many volunteers who give of their free time and I would like to extend my thanks to them for all of their hard work. “Pre-pandemic agricultural shows attracted more than , visitors. It is essential therefore that NI shows have the opportunity to run a full schedule this year to promote and facilitate future economic growth for agri-food businesses and I am pleased that I can support their efforts through the provision of the pound, bounce back support scheme I’ve announced today, which will allow each show to claim up to a maximum of poundk for new or increased costs. “Departmental officials will contact shows directly in the next few weeks to assist them in availing of my support scheme.” Looking to the future, Mr Poots has announced plans for an independent review of local agricultural shows, which will explore the potential for longer term support options and help shows remain sustainable in the years ahead. He added: “Although I am providing support to our local shows this year, I am of the view that Government departments and local councils should consider options for longer term support. “I am therefore announcing plans for an independent review to commence in the next month or two which will aim to explore future support options and guide future policy, in addition to identying new and innovative methods which would be utilised by local shows to help safeguard their future.”

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220327newshargey tackles digital exclusion through provision of free broadband
story: Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey has announced the provision of free broadband for those facing digital exclusion as a barrier to work. The broadband support package will be available to eligible jobseekers through the Department for Communities’ Adviser Discretion Fund, a grant fund available to help remove barriers to employment that prevent people moving towards and into employment Minister Hargey said: “Digital exclusion has been one of the inequalities thrown into sharper focus by the Covid- pandemic. “More than ever, employers are posting vacancies online, with many having moved to online interviewing and more positions requiring people to work from home. “Therefore, not having access to broadband can be a signicant barrier to searching for, or moving into, employment. “I am tackling this by providing free broadband support which will provide broadband for eligible jobseekers who do not currently have the service.” Support for broadband through the Adviser Discretion Fund is available for a period of six months. The Fund can provide a non-repayable grant of up to pound,, in a  month period, to remove barriers to employment. The Minister continued: “The success of the Adviser Discretion Fund in helping remove barriers to employment has already been seen throughout the year, particularly in the uptake of upfront childcare costs, which I made available last October. “I am delighted that we have already helped around  parents with average upfront childcare costs of approximately pound. “This additional scheme will help remove similar barriers to employment for those facing digital exclusion due to a lack of broadband service.”

title: council commends autism friendly sessions at local attraction
story: MID and East Antrim Borough Council has commended a local business on the launch of a new initiative aimed at autistic children and their families. Commencing on Wednesday  March, Fun Factory Ballymena will host a series of quiet play sessions for autistic children, during which visitor entry numbers will be signicantly reduced, lighting will be dimmed and no loud music will be played. A six-month pilot of the initiative, which is supported by Council’s Community Planning Partnership, will see the sessions offered on the last Wednesday of every month between March and October from .pm to .pm . The sessions align with Mid and East Antrim Borough Council’s strategy to make Mid and East Antrim an Autism Friendly Borough as part of its Community Plan. Partnering with a wide range of organisations, including The Fun Factory, Council is creating a strong, vibrant, safe and inclusive community in which local citizens, businesses and community organisations work together to improve the lives of everyone. Council remains strongly committed to ensuring Mid and East Antrim is an accessible, safe, welcoming and inclusive place for every person living in or visiting the Borough. In , it was awarded the prestigious ‘Autism Impact Award’ for six of its venues in recognition of “going above and beyond” to create accessible and ‘autism-friendly’ environments – including Seven Towers Leisure Centre and The People’s Park. These award accreditations were presented by Autism NI, in partnership with the Northern Health and Social Care Trust .Pamela, Manager of The Fun Factory, commented: “The Fun Factory is very much behind Council’s ambition to be as accessible and inclusive as possible for every person of every age, background and ability living in or visiting our Mid and East Antrim – it’s something we very much strive to achieve in our own business. “We passionately believe that every child deserves the chance to have a fun and enjoyable experience in an environment in which they feel safe and comfortable. Council has been fantastic in helping us to understand the challenges faced by autistic children and their families and supporting us to develop these new quiet play sessions.”For more information about the sessions, please visit www.thefunfactoryni. Sessions can be booked via telephone by calling   .

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220329newsbooster third dose milestone welcomed
story: The number of COVID- vaccine boosters and third doses administered in Northern Ireland has passed the one million mark. The milestone has been welcomed by Patricia Donnelly, head of Northern Ireland’s vaccination programme. She said: “GPs, community pharmacists and Trusts have all worked extremely hard to roll out the booster campaign, with the period in the run up to Christmas particularly busy. “They all deserve our heartfelt thanks. Because of the vaccines, we now have much greater protection against the virus. “All those involved in the vaccination programme are genuine history makers.” Booster doses have been provided from the latter stages of last year, supplementing the two primary doses already received. At the same time, a third primary dose was offered to people with a severely weakened immune system, which was then followed by a booster three months after their third primary dose. The latest tallies on Northern Ireland’s vaccination dashboard include , boosters and , third doses. Patriciacontinued: “While demand for vaccines is no longer at levels from the peak of the campaign, people are still coming forward on a daily basis for boosters and first and second doses. “It’s still not too late to get these jabs. Please do so - and benefit from the really important protection they bring.” The one million landmark has been reached with the Spring booster campaign imminent. In line with UK-wide guidance set by the JCVI, the Spring campaign will offer an additional booster dose to: anyone who is aged  or over care home residents and anyone aged  and over who has a severely weakened immune system. Further details can be found on NI Direct:www.nidirect.gov.uk articles get-covid--vaccination-and-booster-northern-ireland

title: northern ireland spring booster vaccination to begin in april who is eligible
story: Northern Ireland#s Spring booster programme is to begin this week: Danny Lawson PA WirePA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNorthern Ireland#s Spring booster programme is to begin this week: Danny Lawson PA WireAllan PrestonTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailNorthern Ireland’s Spring booster vaccination programme is to get under way in the coming days.The Public Health Agency is now encouraging those eligible to book their appointments.Those over , residents in care homes and those over -years-old with a weakened immune system will be offered the added protection against Covid-.Read MoreCoronavirus Northern Ireland: Five deaths and , new casesIt’s advised that the booster should be offered around six months after an inidual received their first booster dose.Dr Jillian Johnston, Joint Interim Assistant Director in Health Protection at the PHA, said: “COVID- is more serious in older people and those with a weakened immune system. Protection from the vaccine may be lower and may decline more quickly in these people.”She explained that while vaccines provide good protection against severe Covid- disease, protection against the Omicron iant seems to decline quickly even after a booster dose.She said the spring booster dose would help to address this.“This spring booster is being offered as a precaution to those at extremely high risk, most of whom received their first booster around six months ago. If the number of infections increases over the summer, this booster should help to reduce your risk of being admitted to hospital with Covid-.”The spring booster programme will begin in care homes from the start of April and will be carried out by community pharmacies.GPs will invite all their eligible patients who are aged over  for vaccination.They will also have the option to receive the booster at a participating community pharmacy or at a HSC Trust-led vaccination clinic.Health Trusts will also continue to run some vaccination centres as well as mobile clinics pop-up clinics.District nursing teams will continue to vaccinate the eligible housebound patients.Immunosuppressed iniduals are also eligible for the spring booster as long as there is at least three months since their previous dose.The Public Health Agency say Trust clinicians should write to advise their patients of this while GPs should provide a “safety net” service.Practices will be able to offer vaccination to any of their registered patients who meet the criteria of immunosuppressed at patient request of by practice identication.“COVID- has not gone away and we would urge those eligible to come forward for the spring booster when invited,” added Dr Johnston.Further infromation is available online at www.pha.site springbooster or by visit the NI Direct website.Most ReadTwo arrested and Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsNorthern Ireland Assembly election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumDUP running out of time to catch Sinn Fein but vote-shares don’t always translate to Assembly seatsBill WhiteExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseSinn Fein Stormont leader Michelle O#Neill. Pic: Jonathan McCambridge PA WirePA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSinn Fein Stormont leader Michelle O#Neill. Pic: Jonathan McCambridge PA WireMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe results are in from our Spring  NI ‘Tracker’ poll, and we see that Sinn Fein are still comfortably in the lead as Northern Ireland’s largest party on a projected % vote share - up a % point from our Winter poll in January.Sinn Fein have now been the lead party in all polls for some time, and so they must be really hoping that they can achieve top spot in the May  election.The DUP are up two points in second place on %, and are seven points behind Sinn Fein.The other two unionist parties have dropped a bit, with the UUP on % - down a point since our January poll, and the TUV on % . Even so, this % score is still three times more than the TUV achieved in the last NI Assembly election in .So the trend is good for the DUP with perhaps some of their regular voters who moved to the TUV ing to the fold as the Assembly election approaches.However they still have a big gap to make upthey are to catch Sinn Fein, and there’s not much time left.The SDLP are at least consistent in the polls, coming in this time at % - no change from our Winter poll in January.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up  Read MoreLucidTalk opinion poll: Sinn Fein’s Michelle O’Neill nudges closer to top Stormont post as DUP lags behindThe SDLP has been showing around the %-% vote-share mark for a long time, with no real up or down movement either way. Alliance are at %, up  points, perhaps benefiting from the UUP’s small drop.About this UUP drop, it’s noteworthy that Doug Beattie’s personal ‘leader rating’ in this poll was down  points from his January poll score, which is a hefty drop.Perhaps the Twitter posts controversy has been a factor here, and interestinglythis seems to have had more of a negative impact with female voters than males.Boris Johnson had the biggest increase in our ‘leader ratings’ - up  points from his January poll-score. This reflects the national UK-wide polls with the PM benefiting from a ‘Ukraine war bounce’. However, he still remains Northern Ireland’s lowest rated political leader at minus !Now the science of opinion polling applies to modelling and forecasting NI-wide public opinion, ie projecting vote-shares – that’s what polls do, and they usually do this pretty accurately.Read MoreSuzanne Breen:OpinionWith five weeks to go until Northern Ireland election, Sinn Fein remain in pole positionJon Tonge:OpinionAlliance on course to be third biggest party in the NI ExecutiveBut, of course, what people really want to knowis how all these vote-shares would translate into seats at the Assembly election.As the political commentators will tell you, vote-shares don’t always translate neatly into NI Assembly seats.Indeed, it’s perfectly possible for the TUV to get a %-% NI-Wide vote-share in this election, and for Jim Allister to still be the only TUV MLA – although, with that NI vote-share, they would have to be a bit unlucky for that to happen. It’s all down to where, and in what constituencies, the votes come from.So for our last pre-NI Assembly election pollwe will be running  separate NI constituency polls with the named candidates and parties for each constituency, presented to each poll respondent.Basically the poll-participants will be presented with actual ballot they will see in each of their respective constituencies on election day. Then, like we do with all our polls, we will combine all this data into NI-wide political-party vote-share projections.This approach brings in some of the reality of the election, as there’s always a brand and loyalty factor with some named candidates. We used this approach in our very last pre- UK general election poll, and we believe it was one of the factors that allowed us to forecast that election to within %. We will seeit works as well again – we hope it does!Bill White is managing director of Belfast polling and market research company LucidTalkRelated topicsNorthern Ireland AssemblySinn FéinUlster title: sdlp leader colum eastwood condemns attempts to intimidate candidates
story: The SDLP leader Colum Eastwood has condemned a string of attempts to intimidate his party across Northern Ireland.It follows an incident on Monday night, where the SDLP’s West Belfast Assembly candidate and food bank director Paul Doherty said his team was approached by a group of men on the Shankill Road who told them they were not welcome in the area.Dissapointed to be approached by a group of men on the Shankill this evening and told that we weren#t welcome. This won#t deter me from continuing to work for people in this community. I am running to represent everyone in West Belfast. @sdlplive pic HUmgSjMT— Paul DohertyMarch , In east Belfast, the SDLP’s Charlotte Carson also had election posters set on fire on Cyprus Avenue on Monday which required the Fire Service to attend.SDLP election poster on fire on Cyprus Avenue, east Belfast. Fire Service just arrived at the scene @UTVNews pic ZLAJpNuSf— Judith HillMarch , The SDLP’s Strangford candidate Conor Houston also had more than  posters stolen in the Newtownards area at the end of last week.In a statement, Mr Eastwood said: “SDLP candidates are out every day serving their communities and working hard to build a better future for all our people. These attacks on our party, our candidates and our campaign are totally futile - we have come under attack from violent thugs before. We have beaten them every time. We will beat them again.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He criticised those seeking to make the election campaign “a toxic race to the bottom on protocol and identity politics.”“They want to stop us reaching out to the people across all our communities who are begging for help to heat their homes and feed their kids - real problems that transcend political or community background,” he said. Wherever people need help, the SDLP will be there for them. We won’t back down.”He noted the “outrageous” attacks were also focused on a new generation of SDLP leaders.“Paul Doherty - a food bank director feeding hundreds of families every week and delivering humanitarian aid to Ukrainian civilians. “Charlotte Carson - a teacher in an integrated school with a passion for empowering young women and girls. Conor Houston - a man who has dedicated his le to reconciliation and peace building between our communities.“Our candidates are a threat to no one but those who want to keep us all in the past. Paul, Charlotte and Conor are shattering old certainties, they are stepping up and stepping in to put people first. And they will have my support every step of the way.”Posting a video on Twitter, Paul Doherty said he and his colleagues were approached by a group of men as they were putting up posters on the Shankill Road.We were approached by a group of men who said we weren’t welcome in this area and threatened that our posters would be taken down,” he said.What was even more frustrating was the fact that we tried to engage and have a conversation about what really matters.”He said this included issues like health, housing and the cost-of-living.But they were too concerned about certain rhetoric around the protocol. This narrative isn’t representative of the views of many I know and have supported here in this community,” he said.And it won’t deter us to continue to work for people in these areas,” adding that he was standing to represent everyone in the community regardless of their political outlook.It’s time we toned down this toxic political rhetoric and focus on the issues that really matter.”Related Credit: NCA PAPADaniel Canning. Credit: NCA PAPAGary Vickery. Credit: NCA PAPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueConvicted: Thomas Kavanagh. Credit: NCA PARobin SchillerMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe -year jail term handed down to the Kinahan cartel’s “main man in the UK” marks a signicant victory in the fight against the international drugs gang.Thomas ‘Bomber’ Kavanaghoperated a lucrative network which saw more than €m worth of drugs hidden inside industrial machinery being smuggled into the UK in a single year.However, the high-ranking associate will be out of circulation until he is well into his s, when he is released on licence from the longest jail term he has received in a criminal career spanning over five decades.Born on September , , Kavanagh grew up in south central Dublin and was on the garda radar by the time he turned .In April  he picked up his first criminal conviction, and over the next  years was regularly in the dock for offences involving firearms, burglary, making threats to kill and assault.By the turn of the century, he was considered a serious player in organised crime and came into the sights of the recently formed Criminal Assets Bureau .The Bureau later secured an order for more than £, in unpaid taxes from the proceeds of his criminality.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up As a result of the increasing garda pressure, Kavanagh moved his family to the English Midlands in the early s, eventually settling in Tamworth, near Birmingham.He set up TK Motors in  which bought cars at auction before exporting them for profit to Ireland. Investigators believe he made “quite considerable” s from this enterprise which included trading cars across Europe and even in Dubai. However, they suspect he relied mainly on crime to fund his lestyle.While in the UK, gardaí suspect ‘Bomber’ was also linked to major drug shipments imported into Ireland through his contacts across continental Europe.By  his wealth was growing and that year he used fake documents to re-mortgage his £, home, a fraud for which he later received a fully suspended -month sentence. The house was lavishly refurbished, while a state-of-the-art security system, fortied gates, reinforced doors and bullet proof glass were also installed.His influence had also expanded across the Midlands and the National Crime Agencyassessed that his rise led to him becoming the Kinahans’ “figurehead” and “top man” in the UK. While his Europe-wide empire grew, garda intelligence in late  indicated that Kavanagh was rarely,ever, sighted in Ireland. That changed after February , , when his brother-in-law David Byrne was shot dead at the Regency Hotel in Drumcondra. Byrne was considered a close associate of the Kinahan gang in Dublin along with his older brother Liam. The murder would lead to a spate of gun murders, with  people killed in Ireland and Spain.He was a prominent mourner at the funeral  days later where he was joined by associates including feud killer Freddie Thompson and the Kinahan brothers Daniel and Christy Jnr. Also at the funeral service was an unknown middle-aged man, who garda inquiries would later determine was Declan Brady.Gardaí immediately began investigating the unassuming haulier who became known as ‘Mr Nobody’ and would turn out to be Kavanagh’s man in Ireland.The following January, Irish detectives raided a business in Dublin’s Greenogue industrial estate where they found ‘Mr Nobody’ along with two other men and an arsenal of high-powered weapons. More than €m worth of drugs were also seized in a later search.Financial documents led back to a logistics firm in the Midlands linked to Dublin brothers-in-law Gary Vickeryand Daniel Canning .As part of Operation Hornstay, a search at Dover Port in October  led to drugs worth €m hidden inside industrial machinery being seized, and the two men were arrested.Examinations of their devices showed they were receiving instructions from a man referred to as ‘The Gaffer’.Investigators also had to decipher the codewords used “Paper” was money, “Phones” were blocks of cocaine, “Sister’ was the machinery”, “Jelly” referred to Vickery while “Smiley” was Canning.In one email a week before the Dover bust ‘The Gaffer’ told his subordinates: “Ta put safe in sister and jelly b on in couple hours did not want to get him up tis morning from beauty sleep :”.The NCA established that this man was Thomas Kavanagh, who also used the alias Paul Christopher Harvey.The father of six was arrested at Birmingham airport on January , , while ing from a family holiday in Mexico.An encrypted BQ Aquaris device was found in his suitcase, indicating the cartel associate conducted business while on holiday.His luxury home was searched, and cash totalling £,, expensive watches, jewellery and luxury clothing seized. Weapons were also found, including knives, bats, and a pink stun gun disguised as a torch — for which he received a three-year jail term.More trouble was to come when he was charged along with Vickery and Canning in relation to the drugs importation conspiracy.The NCA suspects they imported €m worth of drugs into the UK between September  and October .​​​Judge Martyn Levett jailed him for  years at Ipswich Crown Court yesterday. Vickery and Canning were given prison terms of  and -and-a-half years respectively for their roles in the syndicate.All three will serve half of their sentences out on licence.After the hearing, NCA deputy director Matt Horne described Kavanagh as a “high-ranking member of the Kinahan cartel” and “their main man in the UK”.They will now go after The Gaffer’s assets, including his Tamworth home and any items bought with the proceeds of crime.Most ReadTwo arrested and murder investigation launched after man’s death in NewtownabbeyWatch: Paul Gascoigne caught on camera tripping up child REUTERS Gleb GaranichREUTERSUkrainian President Volodymyr ZelenskyPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA Ukrainian serviceman walks near the wreck of a Russian tank on the front line in the Kyiv region, Ukraine March , . REUTERS Gleb GaranichLisa SmythTwitterMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThree quarters of Sinn Fein voters want the Republic of Ireland to maintain its policy of military neutrality, a poll has found.Only % of Sinn Fein supporters were in favour of Ireland dropping it and joining Nato in the context of the Ukraine war.However, overall, a third of people responding to the LucidTalk survey want the Republic of Ireland to drop neutrality and join and support Nato.At the same time, % of respondents of the poll have said the Republic should remain neutral as Russia continues its bombardment of Ukraine.Around one in seven who responded to the survey for the Belfastsaid the Republic should drop its policy of neutrality but not join Nato, while continuing to support EU foreign policy.Read MoreRevealed: One in seven people in Northern Ireland willing to host refugees escaping the war in UkraineIt comes just days after the Ukrainian president appeared to criticise Ireland for not abandoning its policy or neutrality despite Russia’s brutal invasion of the country.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Addressing the European Council last week, Volodymyr Zelensky name-checked EU member states — noting in turn what he saw as the level of support the country had given Ukraine.He said: “Lithuania stands for us. Latvia stands for us. Estonia stands for us. Poland stands for us. France — Emanuel, I really believe that you will stand for us. Slovenia stands for us. Slovakia stands for us.“The Czech Republic stands for us. Romania knows what dignity is, so it will stand for us at the crucial moment. Bulgaria stands for us. Greece, I believe, stands with us.“Germany... A little later. Portugal — well, almost... Croatia stands for us. Sweden — yellow and blue should always stand together. Finland — I know you are with us. The Netherlands stands for the rational, so we’ll find common ground. Malta — I believe we will succeed. Denmark — I believe we will succeed. Luxembourg — we understand each other. Cyprus — I really believe you are with us.“Italy — thank you for your support! Spain — we’ll find common ground. Belgium — we will find arguments. Austria, together with Ukrainians, it is an opportunity for you. I’m sure of it. Ireland — well, almost.”The Ukrainian leader offered no further reasons for his comment.While fully backing the Ukrainian push for EU membership, Ireland has not abandoned its position of military neutrality in the face of the Russian assault.EU leaders have so far resisted the call to accelerate the accession of Ukraine to the bloc.Taoiseach Micheal Martin has since played down Zelensky’s title: andrews role at philips service didnt happen by chance royal commentator
story: Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of York arrive at a Service of Thanksgiving for the le of the Duke of Edinburgh, at Westminster Abbey in London  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueQueen Elizabeth II and the Duke of York arrive at a Service of Thanksgiving for the le of the Duke of Edinburgh, at Westminster Abbey in London By Catherine Wylie, PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe Duke of York’s prominent appearance at his father’s memorial service was the Queen’s way of showing that her second son still has a role to play at family occasions, according to a royal commentator.Andrew was front and centre of the high-profile occasion at Westminster Abbey on Tuesday, despite paying millions out of court earlier this month to settle a civil sexual assault case.The duke escorted his mother and had a front row seat at the televised service – his first public appearance since the settlement to his accuser Virginia Giuffre. and the Earl of Wessexduring the service "data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk bb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk bb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"   and the Earl of Wessexduring the service "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose and the Earl of Wessexduring the service "data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk bb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk bb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"   and the Earl of Wessexduring the service "The Duke of Yorkand the Earl of Wessexduring the service PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe Duke of Yorkand the Earl of Wessexduring the service Former BBC royal correspondent Peter Hunt said the “downside” of Andrew having such a prominent role is that it is a reminder of his “many errors of judgment that have led him to being removed from public le”.Mr Hunt tweeted that in having Andrew carry out his role, it was a sign of the Queen “endorsing” him, and he told the PA news agency: “It didn’t happen by chance.“He could have sat in the congregation with others, with his relatives, but they actively decided that he would have this role of supporting her.“So she has chosen, in essence, to remind people that he hasn’t admitted any wrongdoing, he’s not guilty of anything, he’s innocent.“And she’s very clearly stating that he has a role at family occasions.”Mr Hunt raised the question of whether the Prince of Wales and Duke of Cambridge would have been supportive of Andrew having this role at the service."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ffdb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ffdb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ffdb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk ffdb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "The Queen and the Duke of York PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe Queen and the Duke of York “It’s one thing to accept that he should attend his father’s memorial service, it’s quite another thing to then give him quite a prominent role, so it was an active choice to give him such a prominent role,” he said.Mr Hunt said he found it “fascinating”, and said: “Did William and Charles try to intervene  And clearlythey did then they failed.”He added: “I think you have to start from the basis that Charles and William will have been in the driving seat with the Queen of removing Andrew from public le.“Both of them will have been very aware of the risks of Andrew having this role, so either they decided that they could justy it on the basis that it was an event for his father, or they did try to suggest this wasn’t a good idea and the Queen chose not to listen to them.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk adf .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk adf .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk adf .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk adf .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_adf-d-ce-aa-bda_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "The Queen and the Duke of York leaving the service PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe Queen and the Duke of York leaving the service Mr Hunt said he imagines Andrew will have been “very keen” to escort his mother, adding: “It would be for others to dissuade him.”The former correspondent wondered how the move will be perceived in the United States and where in the world.“It’s one thing to organise an event to satisfy the needs and the desires of the family members, it’s quite another to then step back from it and see how it is seen around the world, and I don’t yet know what that judgment will be.“But the risk for them is it reopens yet again the whole can of worms for them about Prince Andrew’s judgment. It reminds them about his missteps and it raises questions about the wisdom of allowing him to have a prominent role when he could just have attended as everyone  did,” he said.But another royal commentator said Andrew’s role of escorting the Queen may have been a matter of “practicality” as much as anything .Askedhe viewed Andrew’s role at the service as a way of the Queen showing support for her son, Joe Little, managing editor of Majesty Magazine, told the PA news agency: “It’s hard to interpret how it came about.“I’m not sure that the Queen would necessarily regard it in that way.”He said it might have just been “a practicality as much as anything” and a plan that “fitted the purposes of the occasion”.Mr Little added: “I mean, clearly with him by her side, then the support is there physically and in every other way, really.”He noted Andrew has not been found guilty of anything, adding: “It’s a complicated situation on a very personal level for the Queen as his mother.”Mr Little pointed out that, like the Queen, Andrew travelled from Windsor for the service and it may have “made sense to have a member of the family travel with her”.Askedhe was surprised by Andrew’s role, he said: “I suppose we should always expect the unexpected on big royal occasions, and I don’t think anybody had guessed that this is what would happen.“But I suppose we could look at it in many ways.”He added: “Clearly it’s the first time that we’ve seen him for a long time, since all the legal wranglings were settled, so some people will argue that he shouldn’t have been as prominent.“But then we have to remember that he was the Duke of Edinburgh’s son.“So, you know, really, he is just as entitled to be there as his siblings.” Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletter Receive todays headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter. title: ‘Doughnuts’ and speeding issues on Newcastle road
story: INCREASING concern about the behaviour of motorists on the Castlewellan Road outside Newcastle has prompted calls for a speeding assessment to be carried out in the area.South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Mournes councillor Laura Devlin have been contacted by a number of residents angry about the actions of drivers performing so-called lsquodoughnutsrsquo at the Maghera Road junction with the busy main road.The area is known locally as the lsquoCup and Saucerrsquo and the politicians calling on drivers to show more consideration.Mr McGrath said the Castlewellan Road was ldquoan incredibly busy route and claimed a number of motorists drove in excess of the mph speed limit.ldquoWe must be sensitive to the needs of residents who see at first and what is happening along the road, he said.ldquoWhile speed is an issue which must be considered, residents have had to endure night time activity including drivers pulling doughnuts in their cars at this junction. This is simply not fair on local families.Mr McGrath said a pattern was emerging whereby motorists in Newcastle sped along the Shimna Road from Donard Park and made their way up the Castlewellan Road.He urged police to get to grips with the issue to ensure people who live locally are no longer subjected to such behaviour.Cllr Devlin said the ldquoselfish actions of some drivers were not fair on residents, insisting that she and Mr McGrath will support those affected by the issue any way they can.ldquoWe shall be requesting a speed assessment of the area and asking police to consider monitoring any adverse behaviour, she confirmed.ldquoWe would appeal to local familiesthey do witness any reckless behaviour on the roads that could endanger lives to report it to police so they can gather all the necessary data..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch Camera Club competition in memory of Charlie
story: BALLYNAHINCH Camera Club members welcomed Vitorrio Silvestri, from CPA Camera Club, last Thursday night to judge the entries which had been submitted for the annual Charlie Rutledge Memorial competition.Charlie was a much loved and respected founding member of Ballynahinch Camera Club and his great passion was mono photography.After Charlie passed away in  it was decided to hold a competition each year in his memory and what other genre of photographs could such a competition attract but black and white Vitorrio gave a critique on each image and, in some cases, demonstrated how they could be improved. He chose images from the following club members as the prize winners:st Terry Hanna, nd Muriel Darling, rd Frances Price highly commended and commended, John McCullough.At the end of the meeting, members were given a challenge for the next meeting. The challenge is to produce self-portraits using as much imagination and as many dferent techniques as possible. One such technique could be multiplicity mdash watch this space.New members are always welcome andanyone with an interest in photography would like more details of joining the club they should visit the club website: www.ballynahinchcameraclub..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch road bypass deay
story: FEARS are growing that the start of construction work on Ballynahinchrsquos eagerly-awaited new bypass faces a further delay.It was hoped that work on the multi-million pound scheme linking the Belfast and Newcastle roads would have started soon after a so-called lsquodirection orderrsquo was signed last year by Stormont Infrastructure Minister Nicola Mallon.It has emerged that just a handful of weeks before the Assembly is dissolved ahead of the May  election that she will not be signing a so-called commencement order paving the way for work on the scheme to start.However, Mrs Mallon has revealed that her departmentrsquos funding bid for the next three years included money to deliver the Ballynahinch scheme, explaining that the absence of an Executive means there is no agreed budget resulting in delivery timescales remaining uncertain.The bypass is included in a list of strategic and flagship road improvement schemes alongside Newryrsquos proposed southern relief road, bypasses in Enniskillen and Cookstown and junction improvements along the A.The latest delay in starting construction work has been criticised by South Down MP Chris Hazzard and veteran Ballynahinch bypass campaigner Francie Casement.Mr Hazzard has described the failure to commence the bypass during the current Assembly term as a ldquokick in the teeth for local residents and commuters across the constituency.He said that for more than two years, the people of Ballynahinch and wider South Down area had been waiting for a ldquopositive, proactive statement of intent from the current roads minister regarding the bypass.ldquoUnfortunately, we have been left waiting and the scheme remains on the shelf, the MP declared.ldquoAt just poundm, the project costs for the Ballynahinch scheme are relatively minor for a government department that boasts a huge capital budget of more than poundm per year. The Ballynahinch scheme represents excellent value for money and should have been prioritised during the past two years.Mr Hazzard said more than poundbn of capital resources has been spent by the roads minister and her department during the letime of the current Assembly.ldquoIt is hugely disappointing that a small, yet strategically important scheme, such as the Ballynahinch bypass has been left on the shelf. In light of the economic impact of Covid- and the ongoing Brexit uncertainty, the commencement of this scheme would have been a welcome step towards improving both our local economy and the wellbeing of the local community, said the MP.Mr Hazzard added: ldquoWe can only hope now that when the Executive is restored after Mayrsquos election, that the local community can have a minister in place who recognises the value of the Ballynahinch bypass and finally begins construction.Mr Casement said the bypass could help kick-start the economic regeneration of the town and provide the wider South Down tourism economy with a signicant boost. He said it was vital a start date for construction work is confirmed as soon as possible.A key member of Ballynahinchrsquos Regeneration Committee for many years alongside the late Vincent Fullam, Mr Casement has never given up the battle to secure a bypass, which was first mooted in the late s.ldquoThe bypass is included in a list of strategic projects and is effectively ready to proceed. There should be no more delays. The scheme should have been delivered years ago, he declared.ldquoWhile the primary focus of the bypass is on easing traffic congestion, there are many other benefits, including reduced town centre pollution.Mr Casement added: ldquoThe new road scheme will also dissuade drivers from using built-up housing areas and rural roads as unofficial bypasses and, most importantly, help kick-start the economic regeneration of Ballynahinch town centre. We need to see work starting on the scheme now.A Department for Infrastructure spokesman said it was committed to delivering the bypass as part of a plan to aid economic recovery and community transformation, while addressing regional imbalance.He said that ldquofar from being left on the shelf, the scheme was being actively progressed much further by Ms Mallon than any other minister, with development work now substantively complete and statutory approvals finalised in July last year.ldquoThe next stage would involve commencing the procurement of a contractor but progression to procurement and construction is dependent upon the level of funding made available to the Department in future budgets, he explained.ldquoThe Departmentrsquos bid for the - budget included funds to deliver this scheme, however, the absence of an Executive means there is no agreed budget which means that delivery timescales remain uncertain.The spokesman added: ldquoThis is a priority for our Minister who remains frustrated that once again the absence of an Executive is negatively affecting both the people of Northern Ireland and our infrastructure..prettyPhoto

title: Carryduff landowner helps the environment with trees
story: CARRYDUFF landowner Rosanna Ballentine and her son Iain have received  trees to plant on their farm to help them enhance bioersity and create a habitat for wildle.The trees have been supplied from a partnership between Trees on the Land ndash a charity and not-for-profit project from the Green Economy Foundation ndash and SuperValu and Centra, part of the Musgrave Group.The project is part of a sustainability initiative from the retail brands which recently announced they will plant , trees across Northern Ireland over ten years.Mrs Ballentine welcomed the initiative and the assistance of SuperValu and Centra staff, along with central colleagues from Musgrave NI, who pulled on their wellies and visited the farm to help plant a mix of hawthorn, oak, birch, rowan and hazel trees.She said: ldquoWe are planting a new native hedgerow and a line of trees along the edge of an existing woodland to ide it from an adjoining agricultural grassland. Thanks to Trees on the Land, SuperValu and Centra, we can not only improve bioersity and create habitat for wildle but also soak up carbon.ldquoWe were delighted to welcome volunteers from our two local stores, as well as some of Musgraversquos central colleagues, to help with the tree planting.Already this year the retailers have sponsored , native trees, including  at the Carryduff farm. Centra Carryduff owner David Martin explained: ldquoAt Centra, we care about sustainability and wersquore very pleased to be involved with this project. It was great to be able to help with the planting and hear from Rosanna and Ian about the benefits that these trees will bring.SuperValu store manager Jim Brennan added: ldquoThis is a very worthwhile initiative and will create many long-term positive benefits for the area. We were delighted to help out and this project is just one that demonstrates our commitment to making a positive impact in the communities we serve..prettyPhoto

title: Castlewellan trio in the ‘Big Apple’
story: THREE young Gaelic footballers from Castlewellan had an important role to play in last weekrsquos St Patrickrsquos Day parade in New York.Former Down goalkeeper Michael Cunningham and his team-mates, Paddy Boyle and Aidan Doherty, were given the honour of leading the Co Down contingent in the historic event which was watched by millions across the world on NBC television.All three played senior football for Castlewellan and are still highly regarded in their native Club.Michael was even given a name check by the impressively well informed commentator, who said he was looking forward to playing in goal for New York in the forthcoming game against Sligo in the Connaught championship.The opportunity to lead the Down contingent was described by Michael as ldquoan unbelievable honour and one which he would never forget.ldquoWe all feel very honoured and privileged to have been chosen.To experience the incredible atmosphere, the crowds, the bands, the colour and the cheers was just out of this world, he said.The first New York St Patrickrsquos Day parade was held in  mdash  years before the first similar event in Dublin took place in  mdash and has long been widely accepted to be among the biggest in the world..prettyPhoto

title: Celtic Bhoys lift the   Bobby Dalzell Cup
story: CELTIC Bhoys were crowned Bobby Dalzell Cup champions after defeating local rivals Ardglass in the deciding penalty shoot-out at Meadowvale last Thursday.A goal on the stroke of half-time from Ardglass midfielder Stephen Deegan was cancelled out on  minutes by the close range effort of Celtic striker Jordan McCoubrey.The teams refused to be split in extra-time and following the shoot-out mdash which went well into the sudden death stages mdash Blaine Connolly converted the all-important spot kick to gt his Hoopsrsquo side the victory.A large crowd turned out in Drumaness for the St
